greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle Q, read by rows, where column k of Q equals column 0 of Q^(k+1) and Q is equal to the matrix square of integer triangle P = A135880 such that column 0 of Q equals column 0 of P shift left.
formula: See formulas relating triangles P, Q and R, in entry A135880.
example: where column k of Q equals column 0 of Q^(k+1) for k>=0.
where column k of Q equals column 0 of P^(2k+2)
such that column 0 of P^2 equals column 0 of P shift left.
The matrix product P*R^-1*P = A135899 = Q (shifted down one row),
in which column k of R equals column 0 of P^(2k+1).
program: (PARI) {T(n,k)=local(P=Mat(1),R,PShR);if(n>0,for(i=0,n, PShR=matrix(#P,#P, r,c, if(r>=c,if(r==c,1,if(c==1,0,P[r-1,c-1]))));R=P*PShR; R=matrix(#P+1, #P+1, r,c, if(r>=c, if(r<#P+1,R[r,c], if(c==1,(P^2)[ #P,1],(P^(2*c-1))[r-c+1,1])))); P=matrix(#R, #R, r,c, if(r>=c, if(r<#R,P[r,c], (R^c)[r-c+1,1])))));(P^2)[n+1,k+1]}
results.author: _Paul D. Hanna_, Dec 15 2007
